titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: I attended at the morning Service of St John’s Church. Mr Hawley read prayers for Quinquagesima Sunday, and preached from Hebrews 12.2 “Looking unto Jesus the author and finisher of our faith; who for the joy that was set before him endured the cross despising the shame, and is set down at the right hand of the throne of God.”— In the afternoon at the Presbyterian Church Mr Smith preached from James 2 12. “So speak ye, and so do, as they that shall be judged, by the Law of Liberty.” In this as in others of Mr Smith’s discourses, he inclines more than is usual with presbyterians, to the doctrines of the efficacy of good works. I read also the 9th. of Dr Bancroft’s Sermons, on the corruption and abuses of the papal hierarchy, and the 10th. on the nature of the reformation in the 16th. century—and I read a Sermon of Dr Channing on War, delivered at Boston on the 25th. of January— It is a political pamphlet against President Jackson’s threat of reprizals for five Millions of Dollars; and it is filled with common-place declamation against War— Channing is the most renowned preacher in Boston— He has whenever he dared been a bitter and servile politician in the pulpit—a chaplain general of blue light federalism— War is a fine subject for the rancorous benevolence of politician priestcraft to harp upon— War is always execrable unless justified by its cause and object— But there are philosophical views of War which the benevolent apostles always overlook— This Sermon is superficial, and flat, but is published as a factious pamphlet. Mrs Frye dined with us, and John Connell spent an hour of the Evening with me— In the morning I revised for the National Intelligencer the minutes of the Reporter which Mr Seaton had given me yesterday, of the desultory Speech which I made yesterday in the house, and in the Evening, I endeavoured to arrange the heads of remarks yet to be made by me to unfold my whole purpose respecting the present state of our Affairs with France, and upon which I am again to be disappointed.

My Speech of Saturday was printed so confusedly this morning, in the National Intelligencer as to make much of it nonsense— I spoke of it to Jos. Gales, who sent for his foreman who came to the house and on collating the manuscript with the Paper of this morning,—he saw the gross mistake that had been made, and said the Speech must and should be printed over again— Mr Henderson claimant of a grant to the Representatives of Coll. John Lawrence, and Mr Gilpin sent in and called me out of the house— In the House several petitions, and memorials were presented— On motion of C. P. White 10,000 copies of the report on Commerce and Navigation to 30 Septr 1834 should be printed. Sundry Chairmen of the standing Committees asked to be discharged from further Consideration of subjects referred to them— Hamer’s report from the judiciary Committee upon the public printing was read, laid on the table and ordered to be printed— The Report on the West-Point Academy was discussed till Cambreleng moved to discharge the Committee of the whole on the Union from the further consideration of the Resolutions relating to the dispute with France, and that they be taken up in the House, upon which Wilde called for the yeas and nays, which were 104 to 92— The question first in order was on Archer’s Amendment to my Amendment of the first Resolution offered by C. C. Cambreleng E. Everett made a feeble speech in favour of adhering to the execution of the Treaty— He was followed by Allen of Ohio—Love of Kentucky and Moore of Virginia Evans of Maine; Sutherland, Clayton, and Gilmer, and Lytle, Cambreleng offered to take the words of the closing Sentence of the Minority Committee report, without the words at all hazards. Robertson of Virginia had resolutions of his own to offer— So had Seaborn Jones, and finally Binney came out in a Speech with all his power against my Resolutions, and in favour of Archers— Watmough moved to lay all the Resolutions on the Table— I replied to them all, particularly to Archer on his Resolution Hardin, Chilton, Archer replied to me by long and furious personalities—to which Hawes for me rejoined— I rejoined to Gorham, who surrejoined— The motion to lay on the table was rejected 48. 166. Archer’s Resolution by 71 to 143 Robertson’s and Seaborn Jones’s without yeas and nays, and my Resolution carried unanimously 211 votes—followed by clapping of hands in Gallery and house— Adjourned at Midnight.
VI:30. Tuesday 3. March. 1835. Close of 23d. Congress— Faht 8.

The House met at ten— Several members absent when the question was taken last Evening asked permission now to record their votes in favour of the Resolution— The greatest part of the day was consumed in debating the Amendments of the Senate to the General Appropriation Bill— They had annexed to the items of outfit and Salary for a Minister to Great-Britain a proviso that they should not be paid, unless the appointment should be made by and with the advice and consent of the Senate— I opposed this amendment and the House disagreed in it— The Senate insisted, there was a committee of conference, who agreed that the appropriation itself should be struck out— It was within a half an hour of midnight when the Bill went to the President, but it was carried through— The fortification Bill was not so fortunate— At near Midnight Cambreleng moved as an Amendment to the Amendments of the Senate, an additional Section, placing three Millions of dollars at the discretion of the President, for the military and naval service—and for ordinance and fortifications—to this the Senate disagreed—on the return of the Bill I voted to recede from the amendment, foreseeing that otherwise the whole bill would be lost— The House however insisted and the Senate adhered— The House asked a conference, to which the Senate agreed; the Committee of conference reported, an appropriation of 300,000 dollars for ordnance and 500000 dollars for increase of the navy; but the report was made after midnight and there was no Quorum to receive it— Cambreleng at first delayed and finally refused to make the report— The President soon after Midnight, left the Capitol— The Senate sent a message to the House, to remind them of the report of the Committee of Conference—then a message that they had finished their business, and were ready to adjourn—and while the House were vainly endeavouring to make a Quorum, the Senate adjourned—upon which after an address from the Speaker, Bell in return for an unanimous vote of thanks, at 20 minutes past 3. A.M. the House was adjourned without day— Home 20 minutes to 4.
